document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Australian wolf spider genus Anomalosa Roewer, 1960 (Araneae: Lycosidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Australian wolf spider genus Anomalosa Roewer, 1960 (Araneae: Lycosidae)

figureCitation.captionText-0: FIGURES 1 – 2. Anomalosa kochi (Simon). 1 Male (QM S 36273); 2 Female (QM S 36416), both from Boggomoss, Queensland, Australia. Total length male 5.05 mm, female 5.19 mm.
figureCitation.captionText-1: FIGURE 3. Spinnerets of male Anomalosa kochi (Simon) from Laidley Creek, Queensland, Australia (QM S 61256), ventral view. Scale bar 0.80 mm.
figureCitation.captionText-2: FIGURE 4. Male pedipalp (SEM) of Anomalosa kochi (Simon) from Boggomoss, Queensland, Australia (QM S 36893), ventral view.
figureCitation.captionText-3: FIGURES 5 – 11. Anomalosa kochi (Simon), male (QM S 36714) from Nathan Gorge, Queensland, Australia, female (QM S 36727) from Boggomoss, Queensland, Australia. 5 Male prosoma, lateral view; 6 male eye pattern, frontal view; 7 – 8 Left male pedipalp (7 ventral, 8 retrolateral view); 9 Apical part of bulbus, ventral view; 10 – 11 Female epigyne (10 ventral, 11 dorsal view). Scale bar: 5, 2.30 mm; 6, 0.90 mm; 7 – 8, 0.45 mm; 9, 0.30 mm; 10 – 11, 0.35 mm. The tip of the resting embolus in Fig. 9 is dislodged from its normal resting position behind, and in a grove of, the terminal apophysis, similar to A. oz sp. nov. (see Fig. 18).
figureCitation.captionText-4: FIGURE 12. Records of Anomalosa kochi (Simon) in Australia.

145 ° 15 ’E
, Queensland, Australia ], St. 95 , E. Simon ( MHNP
A 14434
).

A 14434
).

Diagnosis. Males of
A. kochi
differ from A. oz
sp. nov.
in the smaller size of the prolateral tegular lobe and the much smaller tegular apophysis of the pedipalp. Females differ in the epigyne as the spermducts are visible through the integument in
A. kochi
, but not in A. oz
sp. nov.
Overall, A. oz
sp. nov.
is a lighter, brownish species in comparison to A. oz
sp. nov.
, of which the basic colour is black (
Figs 1–2
vs
Figs 13–14
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–2.
Anomalosa kochi (Simon)
. 1 Male (QM S36273); 2 Female (QM S36416), both from Boggomoss, Queensland, Australia. Total length male 5.05 mm, female 5.19 mm.

FIGURE 3. Spinnerets of male
Anomalosa kochi (Simon)
from Laidley Creek, Queensland, Australia (QM S61256), ventral view. Scale bar 0.80 mm.

FIGURE 4. Male pedipalp (SEM) of
Anomalosa kochi (Simon)
from Boggomoss, Queensland, Australia (QM S36893), ventral view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Sternum . Orange­brown; dark brown setae which are longer towards margins.
Labium . Brown; front end truncated and white.

Chelicerae . Dark reddish­brown; covered with dark brown setae that are longer medially; three promarginal teeth, the median largest; three retromarginal teeth with the apical largest and the basal smallest.

Legs . Leg formula VI>III>I>II; coxae light yellow­brown, femora brown, femora II–IV with a basal yellow­brown and a central, less distinct annulation; tibiae, metatarsi and tarsi brown. Spination of leg I: femur: 2 dorsal; patella: 1 apicodorsal; tibia: 2 dorsal, 2 ventral pairs; 1 prolateral; metatarsus: 3 ventral pairs.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 5–11.
Anomalosa kochi (Simon)
, male (QM S36714) from Nathan Gorge, Queensland, Australia, female (QM S36727) from Boggomoss, Queensland, Australia. 5 Male prosoma, lateral view; 6 male eye pattern, frontal view; 7–8 Left male pedipalp (7 ventral, 8 retrolateral view); 9 Apical part of bulbus, ventral view; 10–11 Female epigyne (10 ventral, 11 dorsal view). Scale bar: 5, 2.30 mm; 6, 0.90 mm; 7–8, 0.45 mm; 9, 0.30 mm; 10–11, 0.35 mm. The tip of the resting embolus in Fig. 9 is dislodged from its normal resting position behind, and in a grove of, the terminal apophysis, similar to A. oz
sp. nov.
(see Fig. 18).

FIGURE 12. Records of
Anomalosa kochi (Simon)
in Australia.

subSubSection.paragraph: Sternum . Orange­brown. Setae as male.
Chelicerae . Reddish­brown; setae and dentition as male.

Legs . Leg formula IV>I>II>III; colouration as male, but central annulation on femora II–IV more distinct. Spination of leg I: Femur: 3 dorsal, 1 ( 2 on right leg) apicoprolateral; patella: 1 apicodorsal; tibia: 2 dorsal; 2 ventral pairs; metatarsus: 3 ventral pairs.

Life history and habitat preferences. Most males and females of
A. kochi
were found in November, but also from August to January. Habitat descriptions include mainly creek banks and the edge of lakes and riverine forests, but also grassy meadows, and open forests and rainforests. There are some reports of spiders being found in sheet webs with a funnel retreat, apparently similar to the webs of
Venonia
. Web­building behaviour, at least temporary, appears to be supported by morphological evidence, as
Anomalosa
, similar to
Venonia
, has elongated posterior spinnerets.

Remarks.
Lehtinen & Hippa ( 1979 )
designated the single male from the syntype series as lectotype of
A. kochi
and, erroneously, one female of five syntype females as ‘alloparatype’. With the designation of the lectotype , all other specimens from the syntype series should be considered paralectotypes (see also
ICZN 1999
, Recommendation 74 F).
